reviewText: The first thing that is apparent from watching this film is that it had much less of a budget than the original.  Opening with scenes from the original doesn't help -- the original film looked great, not only because of the effects work, but the cinematography itself was fantastic.  Once they dissolve to new footage in this one, it's apparent right away that this film looks a lot different.  This is understandable given the difference in budget.Also at the beginning, there is a voiceover similar to the ones used in the first film for the media segments.  However, even though the narrator twice asks "Would you like to know more?", there is never an interface on the screen (as in the first film) with the "option" to learn more, making the voiceover senseless.As for the plot, it's predictable, and the ending...well, the very last minutes are just...disappointing.  Dumb really.  I will admit that the bulk of the film kept my interest, but I found the whole "bug plan" to be ridiculous.  I won't give away the plot (you'll figure it out as you watch the film), but the bugs have a new plan to wipe us out, and exactly how they did this is never explained.  Nor is lead character Dax's murder of his commanding officer adequately explained either (even he doesn't seem to remember exactly why he did it).The effects are okay at parts, sub-par at others.  The gore factor is much lower than in the original film.  Also, if the original film was distanced from Heinlein's original novel, then this film is completely divorced from it.And one othet thing: one of the characters is played by an actress who appeared in the first film, and whose character was KILLED in that film.  This may confuse some people (the actress in question is Brenda Strong, who played Carmen's captain in the original).On the plus side, I found that most of the acting was good, and the lead character, Dax, was especially well-played.It's not a horrible film, but they could've done much better, even with the reduced budget.  It's all about the story.

reviewText: This is a movie that a lot of people have been waiting for.  The end of the last movie made an obvious setup for another film.  The propaganda was still flying and the war was in full swing.This movie takes and interesting point, it isn't an action or a dark comedy, it is more of a horror movie.What the first movie tried to show you was a distilled version of Heinlein's cautionary tale of a millitary dominated society.  Something bright and cheerful on the outside, but scary when you realize what they are talking about.This movie doesn't have as big of a focus, or a fraction of the budget that Verehoven had.  So they focus on a platoon of soldiers caught in a failed nameles millitary movement.  Things are dicey and when they call for support, they are told none arrives.  So they run to an abandoned base and set it up for a long haul.  Classic setup for a horror movie, abandoned base on an unfriendly planet.  Here they find a man who'd been locked up and left behind because he had murdered his superior officer.  When the rest of their team shows up, they have some other stragglers, ones that aren't acting completely normal.This movie had some definite shortcomings, mostly from budget.  You could tell in the several places the director wanted to do more, but of course lacked the money to do so.  The one glaring problem was the lights on the rifles.  To simulate gun fire they put flashing lights on the ends of the rifle to make it look like a powder charge, but you can see the lightbulbs and it ruins the effect.  The FX scenes were limited and felt like leftover scenes from the original movie, but that wasn't the focus.  There were also some scenes that felt cut short, and there could have been more of a buildup.  The pieces of propaganda could have been better.  They didn't use a good voice actor and they almost seemed out of place.The good.  The idea was interesting.  The first movie dealt with a lot of the propaganda and indocrination.  This movie dealt with people that were either becoming dissillusioned with the millitary or the war in general.  The imprisoned officer killed his superior because he was sick of sending soldiers to die.  They also made it feel like it was the Vietnam of the future.  A war that was more of a political gain than the defeat of any threat or expansion of territory.  The acting was good for the most part over the board though there was little time for character development.This isn't the same movie as its predacessor.  I doubt that a lot of people that like the first one will like this one.  But it shows potential for a possible series.  I can see them making several movies showing different sides of the war.  Maybe the next one will show more of the homefront or intelligence.all in all 2 stars for the acting and writing.  hopefully if there is a next one it will have a better budget and not as many restrictions in the production front.

reviewText: How often does a sequel live up to the original?  Let's face it, it's pretty rare that one does, and even rarer that it should surpass it...and given the fact that Starship Troopers 2 - Hero of the Federation (2004) was a direct to video release, I had no misconceptions about this film being better than the original.The film features the directorial debut of Phil Tippett, who's better known for his visual effects work in films like Star Wars (1977), Robocop (1987), and the original Starship Troopers (1997).  Impressive credits, to be sure, but it's a big leap from visual effects to directing...the film was written by Edward Neumeier, who did the screenplay for the original movie, along with writing for all the Robocop movies.  Now granted, given the comparatively minuscule budget of this, many things were going to suffer, but why should one of those things be the writing?  I'll get more into this later.  As far as the stars go, there are no standout performances to speak of, but there are a couple of recognizable faces.  One being veteran character actor Ed Lauter, who's most memorable performance, to me at least, was as Captain Knauer in the Burt Reynolds film The Longest Yard (1974).  Also appearing is Brenda Strong, who was in the first Starship Troopers movie, but isn't reviving her role as her original character died, and I suspect the actress was brought back to add a familiarity element to the movie, but since she's now playing a different character, it only serves to confuse the viewer.  So very sloppy...the actress may not sound familiar, but if you're a fan of the Seinfeld sitcom, you'll know her better as Elaine's sometimes arch nemesis Sue Ellen Mishkie.Okay, what about the story?  Well, here it goes...it takes place a few years after the original, as the Federation seems to have gained the upper hand in capturing the giant brain bug at the end of the first film.  They are now pushing back on the alien bugs, more or less taking the fight to them, and we see a group of soldiers on a fairly inhospitable planet, surrounded on all sides, fending off attacking bugs.  They radio for an extraction, but help isn't forthcoming, but they received word that an abandoned outpost is in the vicinity, and a decision is made to make their way there and see if they can secure a better position.  On reaching the outpost, they discover it's not deserted, but contains a prisoner contained in a cell, an officer accused of killing his superior.  As they begin to secure their position, an insidious plot by the bugs begins to unravel, as they have a new method for dealing with the pesky humans.  It's an interesting twist, but a highly unoriginal element, especially if you're familiar with popular science fiction films.So what's the weakest element of the movie?  I'd say it's a toss up between the directing and the writing...had one or the other been better, it might have propped up the film a somewhat.  The directing is passable, showing a modicum of inherit experience within the genre, but it seemed so flat and lifeless, like someone trying to take ground beef and pass it off as filet mignon...and the writing...ugh...now the original film contained some pretty corny lines, but they actually worked and fit in with the context of the patriotic story element.  The corn gets pretty thick here, too, with lines like, "You're aces in my book!" but given that the story is considerable weaker than the first, these lines only serve to highlight the overall weaknesses of the film.  I was split on the effects...some of it was really good, while some of it really poor...others have mentioned it, and I will too...what was up with the sound effects used for the laser blasts?  The popgun sound effect certainly didn't convey any of the power one would expect from a highly sophisticated piece of future weaponry.  Did I say laser blasts?  We actually didn't see any lasers, as the guns more or less emitted flashes of light...and the sad thing is these details should have been no-brainers.  The sets did look pretty good, as did the aliens.  There's a fair amount of gore, and even a little bit of nudity, although I am unsure what was the point other than guys wanting to see an attractive woman all nekkid (I certainly didn't mind, but nekkidness for nekkidness' sake means the director is playing a slight of hand game with you, "Hey, look at this nekkid woman, and maybe you won't notice the crummier elements of the movie".The quality of the print looks great, despite the actual quality of the picture (most scenes were way under lit), and there are some decent special features including an honest, almost brutally at times, commentary track by director Tippett, writer Neumeier, and producer Jon Davison, a featurette called `Inside the Federation' that delves into the making of the film, another featurette titled `From the Green Screen to the Silver Screen', dealing with the nuts and bolts of the movie, specifically the special effects (seeing as how it this was a direct to video release, the film never actually saw the silver screen, but whatever), and trailers for this movie along with others like Resident Evil: Apocalypse (2004), Hellboy (2004), Steamboy (2004), Wild Things 2 (2004), and Returner (2002).  This website currently listed a DVD-ROM link to a Starship Troopers PC game, but I couldn't find it.  To paraphrase another reviewer, Andy Hall at DVD Times, the original Starship Troopers was certainly worthy of a sequel, but not this one.  More or less, this just ends up being an obvious attempt to cash in on the original, and not an attempt to create a viable franchise.Cookieman108

reviewText: I'm going to set up my own interstellar warning beacon right now in defense of this gory, fun little micro-budget flick: if you aren't prepared to give a sick little slaughterfest a chance, then pass. If you're a gorehound, then why are you even reading this review---go buy this movie! And if you're uncommitted but willing to relax your standards, then you should get a kick out of this cleverly filmed, often engaging, viciously trashy little bug-hunt.I loved every second of Paul Verhoeven's brash, loud, sarcastic and gory bloodbath "Starship Troopers", but I wasn't expecting this low-budget reinforcement to be anything else but a coda to the original classic. I expected cheesy dialogue with a side order of cheese, hammy acting, amateurish sets, poky pacing, blood, gore, lots of goop, and generous helping of alien slime.Not only wasn't I disappointed, but---like the besieged Federation Mobile Infantry in Phil Tippet's wicked little low-budget space-western "Starship Troopers 2: Hero of the Federation"---I was shocked and surprised.Chef Tippett (in his directorial debut---Tippett's specialty is visual effects, notably "Dragonslayer" and "Starship Troopers) served up a chunky and spicy little dinner with extra helpings of splatter, goop, blood and gore---but also added something unexpected to the pot.The result? Tippett has gotten the most out of every penny of his paltry $6 million budget, mixing in liberal amounts of virtually every science fiction and horror flick ever made (ideas from the "Alien" movies, "The Thing", and "Species" are all liberally sampled), seasoning it with ample blood and gore, letting it simmer, and serving up a film that is admittedly derivative, but fun enough to stand on its own.But as one Federation Sky Marshall once put it, "If we are to Fight the Bug, we must Understand the Bug"---so let's dig in, Marines!The action in this one picks up right after the successful raid on Klendathu, with the Federation sending in wave after wave of Mobile Infantry deep into Bug Territory. The Objective: move in hard and fast, and KILL THOSE BUGS DEAD! Alas, things go wrong, communications break down, and faster than you can say "Little Bighorn" our boys and girls find themselves outnumbered and in retreat, with their options pretty much limited to becoming Bug chow.Every last stand has to have its Fort Apache, and "Starship Troopers 2" is no different: within the first few minutes of the film, the Marines discover an abandoned military outpost, double-time everybody inside, and with the help of a tech officer (played to the hilt by Bryan Tee, who titters, stutters, and leers to great effect) get the perimeter bug-defense (think of a military-industrial bug zapper) up and running, and dig in. With the arrival of a major Federation General (played with spit and polish and a litle bit of hellraiser by Ed Lauter, who channels Patton in his cigar chomping role) and an Evac Boat on the way, why worry?Because the Marines have a new buddy, confined in the brig of the abandoned base with "Murderer!" spray-painted across the locked cell door: a former Mobile Infantry Captain V.J. Dax (Richard Burgi, whose flawless delivery and carriage carry the movie). Should he stay or should he go?Oh, and there's another cause for concern: evidently Psi-Ops messed up with the Brain Bug, and somehow missed out on the Bugs' new Secret Plan---and now the Plan has been unleashed in the Base. Discipline breaks down, marines start coming down with nasty sweet tooths, and formerly comatose Private Soda (yummy Kelly Carlson) is slinking around the base as an equal opportunity vamper. Worse still, the marines who are acting "buggy" are all trying to spend quality time with General Shepherd. Things go quickly downhill, and get slimier, from there.Tippett and cinematographer Christian Sebaldt have turned in a tightly edited, often taut, occasionally disturbing, competently filmed little sliver of space-grue that looks like it was shot for 10 times its budget: every penny is up on the screen. The sequences in which the Infantry is running for the abandoned base is almost startlingly beautiful: marines darting across the sere and wasted landscape, harried by a vicious dust-storm, dodging between the twisted iron tank barries, as the hulking, hunched, freakish base station looms above them, capped off by an evil yellow sky.With the exception of the retreat on the planetary surface, the movie takes place in the claustrophobic, ill-lit confines of the outpost. Tippett and Sebaldt make the most of the dark and moody industrial sets, coupling cramped and confined interiors with a yummy blend of animatronics and CGI; the CGI effects are some of the best I have seen in any film. When the "new" bugs make their debut, the effect made my skin crawl.The acting is surprisingly good for a low-budget B-movie: Burgis (Dax)has some solid acting chops and provides the film's Riddick-like amoral center. Lock and Load, Captain! Lauter (General Shepherd) has a cigar-chomping helluva good time and lets his big bald head carry the role.Kelly Carlson (Private Soda) made me nostalgic for Dizzy Flores, but vamped like a champ. Larry Monoson (Lt. Dill)did a Bolshevikian turn as the squad's underconfident Psi-Op: his nervous zealotry gave the flick a nice extra layer. Ed Quinn and Brian Tee (Corporals Griff and Kobe) leered and grinned as if their lives depended on it.In the end, "Starship Troopers 2" is a rousing little military romp through Bug Country and a gore-hound's dream. If your expecations are low, you should enlist---you'll have a good time. While I'm waiting for a proper sequel (preferably helmed by Verhoeven), I'll join up with the Mobile Infantry on any adventure and see the Galaxy.Service guarantees Citizenship!JSG

reviewText: Starship Troopers 2. This is one movie I have to say I am glad I didn't have to spend money on having gotten it for free from an old friend.Starship Troopers 2 follows a completely new set of characters--none of whom you will likely care about in the very least until the very end--from the first movie. There was little to no character development whatsoever. Though I think Dax was by far the best character in the movie. Unlike in the first where you could feel for Johnny when got ten lashes or when Dizz was killed or the awesomeness of Michael Ironside, I couldn't give a rat's tail about any of the characters or feel loss when one died. It was a simple shrug-off without a second thought for most of the characters.Honestly, the tone of the movie was so (extremely) different from the first movie, it was almost hard to believe I was watching a movie calling itself a sequel to Starship Troopers. Whereas the first movie was an entertaining satirical and enjoyable romp of a sci-fi movie, the people behind this movie took a different route as a movie that took itself too seriously. In all honesty, I think this movie very well may have benefited to some extent by being a stand alone movie of its own instead of being a sequel.This time around, the movie went from being mostly a military sci-fi movie about an army fighting the Bugs that was meant to be satirical and not taken in any seriousness to more a horror sci-fi type with bugs infecting and controlling the human characters that felt like it was trying to be a very serious sci-fi movie.All in all, I can't say I enjoyed the movie when I watched it. Dax (who actually was originally going to be Zim from the first movie) is likely the only redeemable feature but even that is not worth it. However, I feel it should be pointed out that ST 2 was made on a much lower budget than the first so maybe they did what they could with what they had. As I said, perhaps this movie would have been a bit more enjoyable had it not been meant as a follow-up movie.

reviewText: I found the first movie slightly enjoyable to watch, although I did not love it.  This movie, however, is awful.  That is apparent from the first thirty seconds. It's like they have forgotten centuries of combat and returned to the days before someone invented the cannon. reviewText: As fans of 'Starship Troopers' know, the very name 'Starship Troopers' implies a galaxy-sweeping epic with lots of violence, gore, heroism, humor, drama and tons of big-budget special effects.This one is limited to one location, his lots of gore but  little in the humor, drama and big-budget special effects department.One has to wonder at the thought processes in Hollywood. 'Starship Troopers' was a big success. Sure, it was expensive, but it is also a regular staple on cable TV and it continues to sell well (#2500 or so on Amazon in DVD sells as of today - which isn't bad for a 10 year old movie).One would think that a Starship Troopers 2 would have been in the works for a long time - perhaps a final push to the bug home system. Instead, according to the director's commentary track, the special effects director of the original Starship Troopers came up with this simple, low-budget plot that he wanted to direct.  Somehow sold it to the powers-that-be at Sony and they backed it, provided that he slash his already bare bones budget even more.So, what do you get when you give Starship Troopers 2 a budget that is only 5% (yes - five percent!) the size of the original movie? A bad movie full of special effects tricks that you are most likely to see in 50s sci-fi cult classics. The movie's premise changes from being a war epic to being a haunted castle movie, a premise that the producers and director freely admit to on the director's track. They also admit to it being a "B movie" and that it was intentionally filmed to go straight to DVD. Some reviewers have made comments about it being a poorly-lit movie. That was also intentional - poor lighting means that the movie's special effects can be of lesser quality. Unfortunately, one of Tippett's other compensations for a low budget is to add more blood to every scene in the last half of the movie. It gets silly after a while, rather than dramatic.The movie is derivative of several other movies and TV shows including:-Star Trek: TNG. Remember the plot that Picard uncovered in which aliens were physically inserting themselves into the brains of high-ranking members of Star Fleet? Well, I hate to write a spoiler, but...X-Files. Same as a aboveAliens - there's a scene that just steals from the one in which the Paul Reiser character drops an alien into Ripley's sleeping quarters.Alien - the dark sets with a creepy monster about.John Carpenter's 'The Thing' - the premise of being an outpost cut off from the rest of humanity while an alien takes people over one by one. The scene where the General is chased into the base steals from the one in which the dog in 'The Thing' is chased to the Antarctic research lab by the helicopter.Brenda Strong comes to this movie as a familiar face, but not as the same character. Her character in the original Troopers was a fleet captain who died a horrible death. In this one she is an army sergeant. No one is quite sure why they felt the need to have a face from the first mivie but she does a good job and on the director's track they credit her with making this movie shoot a positive experience on a lot of levels. That makes it all the more bizarre that her name is not listed on the cover of the DVD or on the back cover credits. Too bad - her character was just about the closest thing that I found to believable in the whole movie.I give this two stars rather than one because I found the director's/producer's track to be quite fascinating. Maybe it should only be watched with that track playing.I give this one a D-. It fails to deliver on the promise of the original in so many ways.

reviewText: Following the success of the original, "Starship Troopers 2 Hero of the Federation" arrives as a direct to video follow up to the original film. Loosely based on the classic Robert Heinlein novel, the original film followed the exploits of a group of young men and women who join the military in an effort to gain full citizenship in a futuristic Earth and soon find themselves in an all out war for survival against a hostile species of giant insects who have attacked Earth.The sequel follows a new group of troopers some five years later in the war. Due to the limited budget of the sequel, the action is on a smaller scale, as the creative team has opted for a smaller and more personal story.On the remote outpost of a band of troopers have retreated from a bug attack and find shelter in an abandoned outpost. As stragglers from the battle start to arrive, the troopers struggle to get the power restored in order to activate the outpost defenses, as swarms of bugs will soon be massing upon their position.The troopers soon discover that the outpost is holding a prisoner Capt. Dax (Richard Burgi), who was imprisoned by his former unit for murder, and left behind when they pulled out. Since Dax is a decorated veteran, it is decided by the troopers to free him in order to use his experiences in the current crisis.Unknown to the troopers in the outpost, the bugs have a new weapon and are able to take control of a person from the inside. It is at this point that the film loses much of its momentum as instead of keeping viewers in the dark as to who is and who is not infected, the infections and those behind it are shown clearly and often destroying any suspense. I had thought we would have a suspense filled story reminiscent of "The Thing" and "The Hidden" where fear and paranoia would run amuck amongst the troopers. Instead the story unfolds without any real tension or payoff. The cast of largely unknowns shows a lot of spirit and enthusiasm for their parts, but they are so generically written that they are not able to do much more than stand around when they are not screaming and shooting.The FX in the film are not bad for a direct to video film as word has it that Phil Tippett offered cut rates on his FX work in order to direct the film.While not a great film by any stretch of the imagination, "Starship Troopers 2" is at times entertaining and should hold the interest of fans of the first film. While I would have liked to have seen the series continue via the big screen, lets hope that there will be a third outing of the Troopers in the future.3 stars out of 5Gareth Von Kallenbach

reviewText: If you liked the satire, comedy, special effects, and action of the original film I can not guarantee your enjoyment of this movie.  Starship Troopers was about the false glory of fascists going to war and the little people being affected by the conflict.  It leads us on an adventure of some youngsters who join the military to become citizens (or to follow girlfriends) of the Federation.  Take all that glory and throw it out the window.  Starship Troopers 2 is once again written by Ed Neumeyer who wrote the original film and Robocop.  Phil Tippet returns from the original crew to direct.  Starship Troopers 2 tells the tale of the war that isn't publicized on TV at home.  The soldiers are fighting on a different front losing men and constantly falling back.  This is the story of battles that aren't one and the mistakes that can be made.  ST2 focuses more on the horrors of war in general and the false propaganda of the "being a hero" of the federation, hense the title: Hero of the Federation.  For a video release this is one great movie.  There are some bad video releases out there such as From Dusk Until Dawn 2 & 3, Boa vs. Python, Python II, and so on.  There are many more bad ones that I haven't seen.  Starship Troopers 2 does not focuse it's budget on satisfying people's perverse desires to see weapons firing off, rather it's money goes more to other special effects such as some awsome CG animation for the "new bugs" that show up in the movie.  There is alot of gore and horror making this more of a horror movie than an action movie, but there is some action; just don't expect the original's epic quality.  The sets and lighting are very well done also and everything seems authentic.  Although there are some ify video release moments in this flick, I'd have to say that it is worthy of the Starship Troopers name, and it's very entertaining, but if you're spoiled and only appreciate big budget hollywood Spielberg movies than don't bother with this.

reviewText: Let me start by saying that I don't like giving bad reviews, but I'll make an exception for this clunker.  "Starship Troopers 2-Hero of the Federation" is one of the most boring films I've ever watched.  First of all, it attempts to imitate the original flick with its slick advertisements for the Federation.  They were fun in the first film, and scattered apart just enough to keep you interested.  In this sequel, you get one at the beginning and one at the end, and neither is fun to watch.  The entire film is dark, and it's really hard to watch a movie when you're squinting eighty-five percent of the time.  Fortunately, the darkness helps hide many of the shortcomings special effects-wise.  The new little bugs are fake looking and don't match up to any of the bugs in the first flick.  It's sort of like "Tremors" in that the original creatures are so good that it's hard to top them, no matter how outrageous the new creatures become.The poorly-lit sets might hide the subpar FX, but nothing can hide the agonizingly slow pace of the film.  It's just downright boring.  The acting is what you'd expect from a cast chock full of relative newcomers.  Richard Burgi does an excellent job as Dax, but he isn't enough.  He and Ed Lauter were the only characters that I really liked.  Lauter is good as the the stereotypical, pain-in-the-rear, gung-ho general.  His character is similar to Michael Ironsides' character in the first flick, but with a little more R. Lee Armey thrown in. reviewText: When I saw "Starship Troopers" I appreciated the idea of having a computer generated giant army of giant bugs running across an alien landscape to attack a human army.  After all, such a movie would just be an extension of the giant mutant insect movies of the 1950s, most notably the ants from "Them!" and the grasshoppers from "Beginning of the End."  But while the CGI was pretty good and the idea of the bugs' bio-weaponry (reminiscent of what the sentient dinosaurs came up with in Harry Harrison's "West of Eden" series) somewhat fascinating, I had trouble getting past how stupid it is to send ground troops against the giant army of giant bugs.  Ever since Billy Mitchell proved the military utility of dropping bombs from airplanes air superiority has been a key part of military doctrine, which makes the people in charge of the war against the bugs in "Starship Troopers" functional idiots.That being said, "Starship Troopers 2: Hero of the Federation" actively embraces the idea that group troops are just meat for the grinder in the war against the bugs.  On a distant planet things are going bad for the Mobile Infantry and after a battle against the bugs the survivors are holed out trying to wait for rescue before they get overwhelmed.  The situation looks grave, not just because there are thousands of bugs outside, but also because tough Sergeant Dede Rake (Brenda Strong) has to take orders from a lieutenant who might be a psychic but knows nothing about field command.  Fortunately Private Lei Sahara (Collen Proch), who has some psychic ability, knows enough to let Captain V.J. Dax (Richard Burgi) out of his cell.  Dax knows officers only want to get troops killed and knows how to fight, so that helps the odds for this group.  That is until General J.G. Shepherd (Ed Lauter) shows up with some more survivors, including Private Charlie Soda (Kelly Carlson).  Having a general moves the group up on the priority list for being evacuated, but it is the unconscious blond who could prove to be the death of them all.The most interesting thing on this DVD was the point in the featurette when they talked about how this movie was in the spirit of movies about the Korean War.  That is the sort of statement that makes you stop dead in your tracks with a quizzical look on your face, but what they mean is that this is a war fought by more grizzled troops than what you see in a World War II movie.  Of course this is because they are basically the same men fighting again 5-10 years down the road.  This is an interesting idea, but given that ground troops are being chewed up and spit out by this war they should have run out of grizzled veterans a while back and we should be seeing even younger kids getting torn to pieces by the bugs.  Consequently, this film also fails itself by its own rules.Despite the Korean War allusions this film is more in keeping with the last outpost battle story usually associated with the American West or the French Foreign Legion (they really do not have enough starship troopers to justify a comparison to the Battle of the Alamo).  For that matter, from the science fiction perspective the film will remind you more of "The Thing" (the John Carpenter remake based on the original John W. Campbell short story "Who Goes There?" and not the classic black & white film with James Arness as the carrot monster).  Of course, this just moves us further and further away from the original, which has its value in sequels to be sure, but this is a distance too far.  I have to admit that, yes, part of "Starship Troopers" was the discovery that there was a new type of bug, the big brain, so having another new type of bug is a valid story idea.  But if you let Phil Tippett, who did the visual effects for the original direct this one, then you really have to expect a bit more in terms of visual effects than you get here, even if this is nothing more than a low budget sequel.The characters are all familiar types from such films and the performances by Burgi and Strong manage to avoid going over the top, which is always a pitfall with these types of roles.  But I cannot help but feel that this storyline would be better served as an episode in a television series than as a direct to DVD (and television) effort.  I know that the ending of this one was supposed to be an example of cynical irony, but it was a bit too heavy handed for my taste and came across as adding insult to injury, so I decided to round down on this one.
summary: You have to wonder why they bothered to make this low-budget sequel

reviewText: Criticisms first: the over-riding sense of irony of the first film is not present here, which was a script writing decision by Ed Neumeier, writer of both movies. This film also does not match the huge action/FX scenes of the first film, a necessary result of the very limited budget (also, the studio forced them to use an inferior camera, which for technical reasons meant the uniforms from the first film could not be reused, so they had to pay for new ones). As a result, this film is not like the first one. Let's acknowledge this and move on from there...The opening and closing sequences are the least impressive parts of the movie, and it's here that the budget limitations really show. I think we can forgive this, based on the infinitesimal budget (5% of the first movie's), and the higher quality of the main, middle part of the film. Once we get past the cheesy skeleton shot, this movie really comes into its own area of excellence.Beyond the above criticisms, this movie is surprisingly good, considering all the production limitations. There is an interesting variety of well-delineated characters, and the acting ranges from acceptable to excellent. The set design and cinematography are terrific, especially given the budget. The detail, textures, colours and angular design, combined with clever lighting, create a believable, lived-in "used future" environment that seems more claustrophobic as the film progresses. The effects (produced by the same people who worked on the first movie) are excellent - In fact, I sometimes had to make a conscious effort to notice when they were used.While Alien has been cited as a prime influence here, I'd say this film's true ancestors are 1950s classics The Thing (From Another World) and Invasion of the Body Snatchers. The script, by Ed Neumeier, holds together well despite some scenes being omitted due to budget restrictions. A interesting surprise is the outright horror tone that emerges in the second half, at some moments recalling the gore of various low budget classics from the eighties, but with more polished visuals and heavier psychological subtext.As Ed Neumeier notes in the commentary, one of the more horrific moments of the final act involves no gore at all - it is a speech by the bugs about the human delusion of individual importance. Like being held under the magnifying eye of an utterly alien species, it gives one the existential creeps - director Tippett rightly suggests the word "Lovecraftian" to describe the effect of this scene.The climactic scene was shot in one day (!), with a final shot suggested by Paul Verhouven, who directed the original. This scene works, but is slightly undermined by the needlessly Heroic music. The short epilogue has been edited clumsily, and shoots itself in the foot several times, but fortunately is not bad enough to undermine the preceding hour and a half. Overall, I was agreeably surprised by this movie. The elements come together very well: considering its budget, it looks great, is well acted, and towards the end is more gripping than any film I have seen for quite some time. With a couple of million extra to fix the opening and ending segments, I think this movie could have held its own at the box office.(3 1/2 stars.)

reviewText: I might as well re-draft this review as only 0 of 2 people enjoyed the first draft.  That's wouldn't normally phase me, but I can do better for you in this case.I first saw a segment of ST-2 on cable and mistook it for an anemically budgeted direct-to-DVD release.  This ticked me off a bit because I'm a fan of Phil Tippett, who got his major feature film directorial shot on this movie.Having now got the DVD, I have unreeled it from the beginning and I find it loads more ambitious, intelligent and well rendered by director Tippett than I had given the producers credit for permitting.Tippett has been an innovator in the CGI field -- stop-motion, go-motion, and transitional model-to-CGI models manipulated so as to provide dynamic effects for an impressive array of digital creatures. Among those milestones are the perfectly convincing insect creatures in the first STARSHIP TROOPERS movie. The multitudes of individually rendered creatures in STARSHIP TROOPERS are spotlessly realistic.As a general rule, if a studio greenlights a movie sequel as a direct-to-DVD release, they intend to suffocate the production -- whether the franchise has been good, bad or mediocre in the market -- by simply failing to provide a generous -- or even a minimal budget -- to sustain life support in any recognizable way.  Trust me -- starve any sequel of support and money and you become a key factor in ruining even the best of franchises.STARSHIP TROOPERS (the first) was not a runaway commercial hit on first run, apparently, when compared to its $100 million cost.  But sci-fi buffs are a loyal film audience with eternal memories, and it is certain that this ambitious sci-fi production will continue to attract countless repeated viewings -- and income -- for the rest of the studios' and the filmmakers' natural lives.  Nobody loses on this one.  A sequel is hardly a big gamble if one invests long-term.Regardless of that, director Phil Tippett has not only done an impressive job of directing his first major film, he has also done a very smart job of producing a generous portion of images large in scope and convincing in power within his spare budget.Looking at the bug war scenes in the first act, you might easily not suspect there were any production restrictions at all.  Credit Mr. Tippett for that achievement.  In fact, there are moments that benefit from lessons learned in the first movie, which have added impact as a result.Now for a few notes:  I would have liked to see the bug culture and biology expanded in new, logical ways.  I would like to have seen bug life-cycle mechanics which did not rehash ground covered by other unrelated movies -- what has been done and re-done in sci-fi productions as far back as ALIEN.The creative possibilities for an intelligent multiped, exoskeleton, hive-bred civilization are unlimited.  There is no need at all for the writers or FX techs to resort to the over-used and tired gimmick of an alien climbing from one human's mouth to another human mouth, for example.Nor do we need yet another script in which we revisit the old familiar premise of films from INVASION OF THE BODY SNATCHERS to THE HIDDEN to THE THING that anyone can be inhabited by an alien and still appear normal.  It has been done to death.  Let's move on and discard that whole much copied process.I could tell you things about the way a crawdad captures and eats a minnow from the tail forward that would make your hair stand on end. reviewText: First off, let's get real here, Starship Troopers, the original opus from Paul Verhoven, wasn't the greatest sci-fi movie ever made. reviewText: It's not just a sequel; it's directed by THE wizard of stop-motion animation Phil Tippett, whose creations have been the landmark of the special effects before CGIs invaded Hollywood.  Anyone who remembers the sensation of watching ED-209, lethal cop machine in 'Robo-Cop' knows what I mean.  It was a real treasure, and still is.And he directs a film 'Starship Troopers 2', which is a big news.  And ... what is this?  The result is awfully uninspired, nothing that we like to associate with the name of Tippett.  Sorry if I offend you, but no matter how I try, or you try, this extremely dull  film should not be made from the first at all.The sequel has little to do with the original, though it is about the troopers fighting against the bugs.  This time the soldiers have to retreat to a deserted outpost, around which the big bad bugs swarm, but the humans soon realize that the more deadly emeny is among themselves, in the very place where they should be safe.The script of Ed Neumeier ('Robo-Cop') is terribly insipid, borrowing the various ideas from many horror and sci-fi films of the 80s without adding anything new.  If you are a fan of the genre like me, you will easily anticipate the 'surprise's of the plot, which turn out no surprise at all.More damaging and misleading is that the sequel has no deadly fighting between humans and bugs.  You saw many dead bodies chopped by the bugs in the original, and whether you like it or not, the sickly violent scenes are the strength of 'STs.'  Here, you get none, like watching a cheap and bad made-for-TV film.  And actually the photography (by Christian Sebaldt, 'Fear dot com') is too murky for us to see what is going on.Actors include Richard Burgi, Colleen Porch, Bill Brown, Ed Quinn, Drew Powell, Kelly Carlson, Cy Carter, Lawrence Monoson, Jason-Shane Scott, Sandrine Holt, J P Manoux, and Brenda Strong who comes back from the original (if you remember her).  And aptly cast Ed Lauter is General Shephard.It's dull, dull, really dull 100 minutes, and it does not deserve the name of Tippett.  All I thought about it was -- Why did he decide to do this?

reviewText: From what I had heard and read about STARSHIP TROOPERS 2, I really didn't think it would be that good. I hadn't heard anything positive about the movie and since it was a direct to video release, I wasn't expecting much. I have to say I was quietly surprised. After heavy casualties and losing a huge battle, a small group of marines finds themselves stranded in an outpost base waiting for their rescue ship to arrive. A soldier accused of killing his commanding officer is let out of his "cell" to help as the bugs surround the base. Moments before the security perimeter goes up, they are joined by their general and three soldiers who helped save the general's life. Once the electrical fence goes up all the group can do is wait until their rescue ship arrives. However, things aren't what they appear to be and people and events soon get out of control as the troopers learn about the bugs terrifying new plan.Considering the low budget, STARSHIP TROOPERS isn't that bad of a movie. There are a few unnecessary scenes of nudity and some of the violence seems like something out of a scary movie (there's a reference to GREMLINS if anyone can spot it). Still, the movie ties it together well. No, it's not STARSHIP TROOPERS and it's more of an addendum than a sequel, but if you're looking for a decent low budget sci-fi flick, you might want to check it out.

reviewText: Bad screenplay, occasionally bad acting; the CGI effects are actually pretty decent considering the low-budget, but that's about it.  The particularly notable exception from bad acting is Captain Dax played by Richard Burgi.  Some of you might remember him starring on the UPN show "The Sentinel" and also appearing on the first season of the thriller "24" on Fox.  Maybe not Oscar-caliber, but certainly professionally decent.One awfully annoying thing is that the special effects for the rifles are about as convincing as rifle-shaped flashlights.  That is, when the rifles are fired we see light (like a strobe light) from the barrels, but nothing comes out.  No kidding.  Rifle flashlights inexplicably blow off chunks of giant bugs (in those cases where see firing rifles and bugs in the same frame; in the first scenes of the movie we seldom saw even that).Yes, the direct-to-video means that the budget is low (comparatively low, actually about $6 million).  But this egregiously poor effect downright mind-boggling considering the CGI.The motif of inexplicably underpowered infantry weapons for a futuristic military and lack of artillery support from the first movie is continued here, at least initially.  For a recap, the humans fight an "unprovoked" war against alien bug creatures (one scene of the previous movie suggested perhaps the humans provoked the bugs).  This sequel takes place a few years after the original, and mostly takes place within an outpost, where the protagonist crew is largely isolated as a result of the enemy bug creatures on the outside.  There, a species of the alien bug gets inside people through the face where it grows and spreads.  Add to that the gritty, dimly lit rooms and it sometimes seems like the movie is more reminiscent of Alien than the original Starship Troopers movie.  Starship Troopers featured an assortment of battles in a variety of locations; this one chiefly takes place in a single place.  Indeed, except for the title and the bugs we see in the first scenes, there is little visual connection to its predecessor.The good-old (or bad-old, depending on your politics) fashion nudity and embellished gore often make it look more like a horror flick (with a skeleton zombie, the way one female uses a meat cleaver...).  Still passable as a sci-fi flick, not as passable as a decent sequel.  You're better off skipping this one and going straight to the better movie Starship Troopers 3, where we see the continuation of the Johnny Rico story played by Casper Van Dien, the star in both the first and third films.
